DOC.HEAD: Former Congressman Urges Most Favored Nation Status for Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: The author of a law that discriminates against trade with Communist countries is asking President Bush to remove all tariff restrictions from the ``revitalized nation'' of Czechoslovakia. Charles A. Vanik wrote Bush this week saying the official decrees published by the pro-democracy reformists running Czechoslovakia have ``clearly met all conditions'' of the law he co-sponsored with the late Senator Henry Jackson in 1974. The Jackson-Vanik amendment, which in essence imposes high tariffs on countries that forbid free emigration, was designed to pressure the Communist bloc into allowing Jews and other minorities to emigrate. It forbids granting such countries Most Favored Nation trade status that significantly reduces tariffs on imports into the United States. Czechoslovakia has been actively seeking Most Favored Nation status since early this year, but was told by the administration that dramatic improvements would have to be made in its human rights record. A State Department official said Thursday that consideration is being given to granting Czechoslovakia's wish in light of the fast-paced reforms away from totalitarian Communist rule. The two new Czechoslovak leaders, Vaclav Havel and Alexander Dubcek, were subjected to severe human rights violations under the Communists who ran the country until two months ago, Vanik said. Dubcek was elected speaker of Parliament on Thursday and Havel was scheduled for swearing-in as president today. New elections are expected next year. The new leadership has amended Czechoslovakia's constitution to remove the Communist Party's monopoly on power and the predominance of Marxist-Leninist teachings in the school system. In addition, lawmakers voted Thursday to amend the presidential oath to be taken by Havel to eliminate the pledge of allegiance to socialism. ``The most important thing America can do is provide an immediate fair and equal access to our markets,'' said Vanik, a lawyer in private practice here who was a Democrat representing an Ohio district when the law was passed. ``I urge that you declare this revitalized nation eligible for Most Favored Nation status and the same tariff benefits we extend to all our other trading partners,'' he asked Bush. Bush recently lifted the Jackson-Vanik restrictions from Hungary, granting it Most Favored Nation status in response to moves in that country toward democratic rule. ``He could do the same for Czechoslovakia,'' Vanik said. ``It wouldn't cost him anything and would be a great way to tell them we support what they're doing.'' Bush also has indicated he would be willing to grant Most Favored Nation status to the Soviet Union if it adopts laws, now under consideration, permitting free emigration. Czechoslovakia exports glass products, machine tools and other light industrial goods.
